habitat_description:
Distributed from Labrador and Maritime provinces and south east Manitoba, then along the St. Lawrence River south to north New York, Minnesota, and north Wisconsin. Reports of isolated populations in north Quebec and north Labrador (Behler and King 1979; Conant and Collins 1998). The highest latitude at which any North American anuran is found coincides with the southernmost limit of the mink frog (Lannoo 2005). 
This species avoids rapid currents and prefers quiet bays and protected areas with abundant water lilies (Nymphaeaceae) and pickerel weed (Pontederia cordata), and the borders of sphagnum mats (Lannoo 2005).
The preferred habitat of the mink frog is along watercourse, but more specifically the borders of ponds and lakes or the cold waters near the mouths of streams that drain into these pools (Conant and Collins 1998). These cold waters also must be characterized by dense vegetation, but particularly water lilies. Also uses edges of ponds and lakes with emergent vegetation and/or peaty bottoms (Behler and King 1979). Breeding occurs along permanent bodies of water characterized by high abundance of macrophytes; aquatic vegetation is important for cover of tadpoles (Lannoo 2005).
